(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{n = 1}^\infty \frac{2n + 1}{n(n + 1)(n + 2)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{5}{4}

 First, we decompose $\frac{2n + 1}{n(n + 1)(n + 2)}$ into partial fractions.
 Let \[\frac{2n + 1}{n(n + 1)(n + 2)} = \frac{A}{n} + \frac{B}{n + 1} + \frac{C}{n + 2}.\]Then \[2n + 1 = A(n + 1)(n + 2) + Bn(n + 2) + Cn(n + 1).\]Setting $n = 0,$ we get $2A = 1,$ so $A = \frac{1}{2}.$

 \sum_{n = 1}^\infty \frac{2n + 1}{n(n + 1)(n + 2)} &= \sum_{n = 1}^\infty \left( \frac{1/2}{n} + \frac{1}{n + 1} - \frac{3/2}{n + 2} \right) \\ &= \left( \frac{1/2}{1} + \frac{1}{2} - \frac{3/2}{3} \right) + \left( \frac{1/2}{2} + \frac{1}{3} - \frac{3/2}{4} \right) + \left( \frac{1/2}{3} + \frac{1}{4} - \frac{3/2}{5} \right) + \dotsb \\

 Let \[\frac{2n + 1}{n(n + 1)(n + 2)} = \frac{A}{n} + \frac{B}{n + 1} + \frac{C}{n + 2}.\]Then \[2n + 1 = A(n + 1)(n + 2) + Bn(n + 2) + Cn(n + 1).\]Setting $n = 0,$ we get $2A = 1,$ so $A = \frac{1}{2}.$
 Setting $n = -1,$ we get $-B = -1,$ so $B = 1.$ Setting $n = -2,$ we get $2C = -3,$ so $C = -\frac{3}{2}.$  Hence, \[\frac{2n + 1}{n(n + 1)(n + 2)} = \frac{1/2}{n} + \frac{1}{n + 1} - \frac{3/2}{n + 2}.\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 \sum_{n = 1}^\infty \frac{2n + 1}{n(n + 1)(n + 2)} &= \sum_{n = 1}^\infty \left( \frac{1/2}{n} + \frac{1}{n + 1} - \frac{3/2}{n + 2} \right) \\ &= \left( \frac{1/2}{1} + \frac{1}{2} - \frac{3/2}{3} \right) + \left( \frac{1/2}{2} + \frac{1}{3} - \frac{3/2}{4} \right) + \left( \frac{1/2}{3} + \frac{1}{4} - \frac{3/2}{5} \right) + \dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1/2}{1} + \frac{3/2}{2} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{5}{4}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "series (\<lambda> n. (2 * real n + 1) / (real n * (real n + 1) * (real n + 2))) = 5 / 4"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda> n. (2 * real n + 1) / (real n * (real n + 1) * (real n + 2))) = 5 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: The sum of the infinite series with the nth term equal to $\frac{2n+1}{n*(n+1)*(n+2)}$ is $\frac{5}{4}$.
